column22: See Left Fork Huntington Creek 140600090101. The key concerns and conditions affecting watershed condition affect only the Southern portion of the L.F. Huntington and the Northern portion of Lowry Water. This includes Reeder Canyon northward to the Miller Flat area. These two sub-watersheds contain both recreation and wetland corridors which are home to 50 percent of the wetlands existing on the Manti-La Sal NF and host some of the heaviest visitation found on the forest. Former State of Utah sections 16 and 32 in T15 South, R6 East contain many of these wetlands.  These sections became part of the National Forest System several years ago, but for decades they were used without restriction by visitors.  Several miles of user created roads and motorized trails in these sections are negatively impacting wetlands. The Lowry Water road (NFSR 50038) closely parallels Lowry Water Creek between Joes Valley and Potters Ponds and has three bridge crossings.  The northern two miles of this road is also directly impacting wetlands and the riparian area.  Both drainages provide water for culinary, industrial, and agricultural uses to Emery County. Collectively, these sub-watersheds have impaired ratings for habitat fragmentation, exotic and invasive species, loss of forest cover, mass wasting, and proximity to water. Fish are prevented from moving freely throughout the Left Fork of Huntington Creek aquatic ecosystem due to several reservoirs located in the Left Fork watershed.  There are little to no projects that could be undertaken to mitigate the impaired condition of habitat fragmentation. Exotic and invasive species within the Left Fork of Huntington Creek aquatic ecosystem is typified by the presence of whirling disease and non-native fish species.  Native fish populations are isolated and protected from exotic and invasive species by barriers. There are no additional projects that could reasonably be undertaken to mitigate this impaired condition.

High road densities and proximity of roads to streams present opportunities to reduce sedimentation through road decommissioning.  Road/stream crossings present opportunities to improve aqautic organism passage.  Lodgepole pine mortality due to an ongoing mountain pine beetle epidemic provides opportunities for fuels reduction. Note that project costs may vary from $1,029,500 to $1,599,500.

column22: Upper McKay Creek Subwatershed as well as the rest of the watershed has been a priority for reintroduction of Mid-Columbia River steelhead trout and has had fish planted each year since 2008.  The Selective Water Withdrawal tower constructed in Lake Billy Chinook, built as a result of a FERC agreement with Portland General Electric and The Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, provides fish passage for steelhead trout into the headwaters of McKay Creek, located on the Ochoco National Forest.

Camp Creek is a perennial stream in the Sonoran desert that supports valuable aquatic and riparian habitat. The watershed is heavily impacted by OHV use and contains numerous unauthorized routes affecting watershed condition. A large number of the Forest Service system roads do not receive frequent maintenance and contribute to poor watershed conditions. Forest Service sensitive species include riparian dependent species (Common Blackhawk, Zone tail hawk, speckled dace) and upland species (Gila monster   and desert tortoise). Part of the watershed lies within a Bald Eagle closure. Unauthorized routes encroach into the closure area. Recreation residences have encroached into the channel and floodplain of Camp Creek and their septic systems are located in close proximity to the channel. Invasive plant species affect riparian areas and fuel loading in the uplands.

column22: Farmer Creek is a high value subwatershed within the Nestucca River Focus Watershed.  The Forest and its partners have been working in the Nestucca River watershed for years completing essential projects.  While we have completed many essential projects on National Forest lands, the Forest chose Farmer Creek as a Priority Subwatershed because of the excellent opportunities to work with partners on downstream private lands and address key fish access issues and work on high habitat potential private low lands in addition to completing essential projects on National Forest lands.  This subwatershed is a priority with established, high capacity watershed councils and a Stewardship group.

Watershed is a stronghold for native fish habitat and populations.  Reducing road densities would improve water quality by reducing sediment inputs to streams and would reduce risk of future road or culver failures that could further impair the ecosystem.  NEPA covering watershed improvement work is complete (includes over 50 miles of road decommissioning and/or storage) which was done in conjunction with the Fallen Bear Project, incorporating timber, engineering, wildlife and fuels activities.  Planned watershed improvement work aligns with national and regional strategies and forest plan. Watershed is within the same 5th code HUC as future District priority watersheds (e.g. Gold Creek). High runoff and or flooding may cause road/culvert or bridge failure. Implementation of road work would create jobs for contractors. Watershed improvement work would be cost effective if done in conjunction with current timber sale contract work within the area.  On-the-ground accomplishments would be realized in FY12 and FY13.  The Bruin Creek watershed currently has a WCATT watershed condition rating of “FAR”.  By reducing road densities within the HUC the watershed condition rating would move closer to a “FP” condition.  If road densities are not reduced there would be a risk of the watershed condition moving to an “IF” condition if road failures were to occur increasing stream sedimentation and negatively impacting fish habitat.  Watershed is also located within the St. Joe Wild and Scenic River corridor.

Watershed was selected based upon three criteria. 1) NEPA cleared projects were being implemented or were ready to implement in 2011 that addressed indicators classified as 2 or 3. 2) Watershed was a yellow watershed. 3) Projects have potential to move watershed to green.

column22: This action plan is designed to build upon the 2009 Caribou-Targhee National Forest “Upper Blackfoot Watershed Analysis” which followed the 1995 Federal Guide for Watershed Analysis.  The Blackfoot River and tributaries were once known as a Blue Ribbon trout fishery, containing Yellowstone cutthroat trout.  This area is no longer the Blue Ribbon fishery it once was and the FS has indentified the Yellowstone cutthroat trout as a sensitive species.  This area falls within the heart of SE Idaho phosphate mining where selenium has become a critical water quality concern.  Downstream subwatersheds contain streams on the 303(d) list for selenium.  The Diamond Creek subwatersheds are relatively free of mining impacts.  A majority of the remaining streams within this watershed are 303 (d) listed for sediment, temperature, and/or bacteria (E. coli).  Therefore, improving and protecting these headwater conditions as a high quality refuge is extremely important.  Additional concerns affecting watershed conditions within the headwater are: grazing impacts both on non-FS and FS lands to stream and riparian areas; road/trail conditions and proximity to streams; channel and riparian conditions; health of the forested vegetation as indicated by a poor rating for insect and disease; and terrestrial invasive species also rated poor.

column22: The high porosity and loose, non-cohesive nature of the soils in the Deadman Creek watershed, combined with extensive recreational uses such as off-highway motor vehicles and dispersed and developed camping, have removed vegetation and exposed bare soils.  Bare soil is a source of sediment to creeks and streams as well as dust, which can settle on the leaves of vegetation and on the surface of waterbodies.  Overall route density in the watershed is relatively high (4.4 miles/square mile).  Road density within 300 feet of streams and water bodies is considered poor at 4.08 miles/square mile. The risk of tree mortality is high, with a bark beetle infestation affecting hundreds of acres in 8,000-9,000 ft elevation range, including parts of June Mountain and Glass Creek Meadow.  Fire regime condition is considered poor, with a high likelihood of losing defining ecosystem components due to the presence or absence of fire.

column22: In 2007, the Sandy River Basin Partners completed a habitat conservation and restoration strategy which identified priority locations and priority action types. This strategy is the foundation for the Still Creek Watershed Restoration Action Plan. Still Creek Watershed is a priority watershed because: 1) Top priority for restoration by the Sandy River Basin Partners; 2) Start up funding already obligated ($244K), initiation of WCF restoration could begin immediately; 3) TEAMS Enterprise completing Still Creek Rehabilitation plans (detailed site plans), including flood plain enhancements, riparian plantings, and side channels restoration; 4) Archaeology surveys and SHPO consultation in progress; 5) Restoration covered under Aquatic Restoration Biological Opinion (ARBO), 6) Integrated restoration including: instream restoration, riparian plantings, invasive plant removal, road restoration, and rec. resident compliance will collectively result in whole watershed restoration; 7) 21 years of smolt monitoring and 9 years of spawning surveys in Still Creek document baseline conditions for effectiveness/biological monitoring; 8)100% of planned road decommissioning and restoration completed in 2011; 9) Invasive plants mapped and treatment plan in place for the Sandy River Basin by the Sandy Basin Vegetation Restoration Coalition (SBVRC); 10) Recreational resident (Cool Creek Tract) EA completed in Still Creek in 2009. column22: This sub-watershed is one of the three which make up most of the “Hat Creek Recreation Area”.  This area is of particular importance to recreation because on one end, it abuts Lassen Volcanic National Park, and on the other, it is a short distance from Burney Falls State Park.  Often, all three of these are a part of peoples’ vacations.The consequences of such intense use of the area are that unmanaged recreation and high use of system and user-created roads have caused water quality and bank stability problems.  Riparian vegetation near high-use areas has been trampled and otherwise damaged and removed.  The watershed is particularly prone to surface disturbances because it is on a lahar (debris flow buoyed by volcanic gasses) from the 1915-1916 Mt. Lassen eruptions. BHCCFWG (the Burney Hat Creek Community Forest and Watershed Group - a local stakeholder group to which Lassen NF belongs - see partnerships section for a partial list of participating organizations) is partnering with another R5 collaboration to form the Sierra Cascades All Lands Enhancement Demonstration (SCALE).  The existence of both of these groups means that there is a significant amount of collaboration in all areas of the community.   The local NRCS (also part of SCALE) has indicated that they are considering selecting sub-watersheds downstream in the larger Hat Creek Watershed as their Priority Watersheds.  Therefore, the potential for meaningful and mutually beneficial collaborative projects exists. Lower Hat Creek is designated and managed by the California Department of Fish and Game as a Wild Trout Fishery, and projects on it are being implemented under the auspices of BHCCFWG.  By focusing on the headwaters, we are compliment downstream efforts to improve aquatic habitat. Finally, several vegetation management projects are being planned for this area to restore ecological conditions and improve ecological services.

column22: General Overview of Concerns: Each subwatershed has been impacted to various degrees by roads, grazing, and dispersed recreation (camping and motorized use).  Poorer conditions are also due to impacts from irrigation diversions, roads, channelization, and grazing on private land. Most streams are de-watered in the lower reaches during the irrigation season, severely impacting fish habitat. Fire exclusion and livestock grazing have allowed canopy cover to increase, which has reduced the understory herbaceous cover. Aspen is present in pure stands and mixed with subalpine fir; however, most stands are dying out or being replaced by conifers. Older aspen stands are not regenerating. Many of the conifer stands in the area are old, with high tree densities and increasing mortality from insects and disease. Fire hazard is increasing in conifer stands. The Pinyon-Juniper group is functioning at high risk due to fire exclusion and grazing impacts that have allowed older, close-canopied stands to dominate, with fewer younger trees and herbaceous plants than desirable. Terrestrial habitat is functioning at risk in localized areas due to impacts to habitat from fire exclusion and introduced plant species.  • Important Ecological Values: The three subwatersheds support some of the last genetically pure Yellowstone cutthroat populations in the Raft River drainage. Cottam cinquefoil and Grouse Creek rockcress, Region 4 Sensitive species, are found in this area.  The cool sagebrush, grasslands, and forests provide habitat for sage grouse, while dry forests at lower elevations provide habitat for the Region 4 sensitive goshawk, and Townsend's big-eared bat.

Chicken Creek is a sub-watershed of the Mancos River wqatershed, which is a municipal watershed for Mancos, Co, Mancos Rural Water Company and Mesa Verde National Park. Primary watershed concerns are for water quantity, aquatic biota, riparian-wetland vegetation, roads, trails, soils fire regime, forest cover rangeland vegetation and forest health and water quality.   Water quantity concerns arelate to multiple diversions and degraded riparian conditions in headwater areas. Some roads have deep ruts and are functioning as sediment sources. Soils, particularly in parks and meadows, have been negatively impacted and are experiencing erosion. Ponderosa pine stands are in fire condition class 3 and need to be moved into a less severe condition class. Aspen are also experiencing Sudden Aspen Decline and practices promoting regeneration are needed. There has been historic and current overgrazing.

column22: Fish habitat and water quality have been degraded by past management activities.  Habitat degradation includes reduced channel complexity, river diking, reduced floodplain connectivity, road protection rip-rap, low pool quality and quantity, lack of spawning gravels, and some partial fish passage barriers.  Water quality parameters affected include increased stream temperatures and elevated fine sedimentation.  Specific management activities that have directly degraded water quality and fish habitat include road construction within riparian areas, timber harvest of large trees in the riparian area, instream large wood removal, suction dredge mining, and heavy recreation use within floodplain habitat.  Riparian forest has been impacted by roads, past mining impacts, past timber harvest, noxious weeds, and fire exclusion.  One result of riparian impacts is reduced future large wood recruitment to floodplains and streams – a primary structural component in mountain stream systems that develops and maintains high quality pool habitat and off channel fishery rearing habitat.

In 2008, a large debris flow triggered by an intense localized thunderstorm caused extensive hillslope rilling and gullying of the mid- and lower elevation segments of the Oak Creek watershed.  The debris flow obliterated the Oak Creek Campground, damaged or destroyed more than 50 homes, buried native plant communities and 0.37 miles of roads under several feet of mud and debris, damaged 4.8 miles of roads, and created ideal conditions for the establishment of non-native invasive plants.  More than 800 acres in the watershed were affected by the debris flow (another 400 acres in the adjacent watershed were also affected), and remain vulnerable to accelerated hillslope erosion, higher peak flows, increased sedimentation and turbidity, and the spread of invasive plants.

column22: Watershed is considered functioning at risk. Forest health affected by spread of pine bark beetle and hazardous fuels buildup. Portions of riparian and meadow habitat in upper watershed are affected by off-road motorized use and dispersed vehicle camping in close proximity to streams. Density, condition, and proximity of motorized routes to live water in upper portion of watershed contributes to sediment delivery to streams of the watershed.  Barrier to fish passage present at Cart Creek on Hwy 191. Areas in Bowden, Greens and Mckee Draws are experiencing encroachment of lodge pole pine into open meadow communities.  High turbidity flows entering Cart Creek Bay during spring runoff, maintenance condition and density of system and non-system road and fords in the upper portions of the watershed, soil loss and productivity issues related to unauthorized off-road vehicle use in wet meadows and along powerline corridors, fuel loading and forest health issues associated with bark beetle mortality, localized riparian effects from dispersed camping near streams, conifer encroachment into meadows in Bowden and McGee Draws, fragmentation of aquatic habitat at Highway191.  Ecological values include:  Dutch John Municipal Watershed, Flaming Gorge National Recreation Area, tributary source for Green River Blue ribbon trout fishery.

The Upper Sleeping Child watershed is located within the  Darby Lumber Lands project area and is one the highest priorities for watershed rehabilitation on the forest. Upper Sleeping Child contains several sections of former private “checkerboard” sections that were recently acquired by the USFS. Management by former landowner included liquidation of the timber base with little resource consideration.  Sub-standard and poorly located roads built by the former land owner are in poor condition and are not needed for future timber management.  High severity fire activity in 2000 added to watershed sensitivity, precipitation effectiveness, and increased soil loss.  Road densities, watershed condition, and stream channel condition all fall short of Forest Plan desired conditions.  Bull Trout (Sleeping Child watershed), West Slope cutthroat (Rye Creek watershed), INFISH compliance and State Impaired Waters (303(d) listed) compliance would benefit/improve from road decomissioning and storage activities. Phase 1 of the Darby Lumber Lands project would include decommissioning of former landowner roads and historic FS roads in the Upper Sleeping Child and Rye Creek watersheds.  Total miles to be decomissioned are approximately 60 miles, split between 3 years of implementation (FY13 through FY15).   We are currently pursing additional partner funding for project implementation but is not guaranteed at this time.

column22: This sub-watershed is one of the three which make up most of the “Hat Creek Recreation Area”.  This area is of particular importance to recreation because on one end, it abuts Lassen Volcanic National Park, and on the other, it is a short distance from Burney Falls State Park.  Often, all three of these are a part of peoples’ vacations.The consequences of such intense use of the area are that unmanaged recreation and high use of system and user-created roads have caused water quality and bank stability problems.  Riparian vegetation near high-use areas has been trampled and otherwise damaged and removed.  The watershed is particularly prone to surface disturbances because it is on a lahar (debris flow buoyed by volcanic gasses) from the 1915-1916 Mt. Lassen eruptions. BHCCFWG (the Burney Hat Creek Community Forest and Watershed Group - a local stakeholder group to which Lassen NF belongs - see partnerships section for a partial list of participating organizations) is partnering with another R5 collaboration to form the Sierra Cascades All Lands Enhancement Demonstration (SCALE).  The existence of both of these groups means that there is a significant amount of collaboration in all areas of the community.   The local NRCS (also part of SCALE) has indicated that they are considering selecting sub-watersheds downstream in the larger Hat Creek Watershed as their Priority Watersheds.  Therefore, the potential for meaningful and mutually beneficial collaborative projects exists. Lower Hat Creek is designated and managed by the California Department of Fish and Game as a Wild Trout Fishery, and projects on it are being implemented under the auspices of BHCCFWG.  By focusing on the headwaters, we are compliment downstream efforts to improve aquatic habitat. Finally, several vegetation management projects are being planned for this area to restore ecological conditions and improve ecological services.

column22: Sams Creek–Lost River watershed is a unique area, both above and below the ground. The Lost River flows through, above and below the limestone karst that underlies much of this watershed. As of July 2008, the Lost River cave system is the second longest cave in Indiana and the 26th longest in the US. One of the significant features of the system, a National Natural Landmark, is Wesley Chapel Gulf, located on National Forest System lands which is 8.3 acres large and forms a box canyon with bedrock walls, where the river briefly appears before once again disappearing below the surface. One Federally endangered species of bat, the Indiana bat (Myotis sodalis), has an identified hibernacula within the watershed.  The area hosts hibernacula for many other bats species. In addition, many Regional Forester Sensitive Species including mammals, birds, fish, reptiles, karst invertebrates, and plants have been identified utilizing this area.  Tributaries and streams in this watershed flow into the East Fork White River which contains Regional Forester Sensitive Species and two endangered mussel species.

column22: The Headwater of Sheep Creek is a State 303d listed stream for metals, mercury, and pathogens. Cutthroat trout in the watershed are threatened by habitat degradation, rainbow trout hybridization and brook trout competition. Legacy road decommissioning is a high priority for the Lewis and Clark National Forest. The Little Belts Travel Plan has been completed and implementation of road decommissioning has commenced within the watershed.  The watershed was extensively logged resulting in high road densities which contribute chronic sediment to streams and disrupts the natural hydrologic function across the watershed. The L&C plans to continue road decommissioning work which will have the benefits of lowering the road density within the watershed, reducing the chronic sediment inputs to streams and improve hydrologic function of the drainage.  Another high sediment source is from winter traction sanding along State Highway 89 resulting in improper stream function and has degraded westslope cutthroat trout habitat. Potential partnerships will be Montana Fish Wildlife and Parks, Montana Department of Transportation, Meagher County Conservation District and Trout Unlimited.

column22: The Upper Big Tujunga Creek Priority Watershed is located at the headwaters of one of the main tributaries of the Los Angeles River. The Station Fire (Fall 2009) burned a major portion of the  vegetative cover and the soil surface. This has resulted in the Upper Big Tujunga Creek watershed (and all the subwatersheds of Big Tujunga Creek)  having precipitation events producing much higher than normal surface runoff and erosion. Under these conditions slopes and channels became even more unstable than normal. TheUpper  Big Tujunga Creek watershed had one hundred  percent of the watershed burned which included the higher forested elevations and lower slope and riparian areas. The following activities will be implemented in 2012 to contribute to improving watershed conditions:  plant 245 acres of native trees, release 241 acres of native trees planted in 2011, treat standing deadwood that poses a threat to humans and has potential to contribute to damaging floatable debris through administration of deck sales, noxious invasive weed treatment through partnerships and direct funding, decommission 3 miles of road, alleviate a resource/recreation issue related to the arroyo toad, and conduct trails maintenance work to reduce erosion and sediment from entering  Big Tujunga Creek.

column22: The Cass Lake Watershed is located within 90 river miles of the Headwaters of the Mississippi River.  The watershed is rated as condition class II.  This rating is primarily due to impacts related to Knutson Dam, which is located on the Mississippi River at the outlet of Cass Lake.  The dam has been in place since the late 1800s, was most recently rebuilt in 1946, and is owned and operated by the Chippewa National Forest.  The dam is in need a significant maintenance and has limited ability to manage flows at the high and low ends of the hydrograph.  This results in lake level changes that impact natural flow regimes, channel and shoreline conditions, and recreational access.  The dam is also a barrier to aquatic organism passage which is concern for state fishery managers and the Leech Lake Band of Ojibwe, especially regarding game species and the Regional Forester Sensitive Species listed Greater Redhorse.  The watershed is a major tourism area and important resource for the local economy.  An important opportunity exists for the Forest to work with partners to perform needed maintenance and modify the dam in order to meet lake level targets, provide for fish passage, and facilitate recreational use.  Modification of Knutson Dam would improve watershed condition by improving a number of watershed attributes.  Other watershed indicators that need improvement in the basin include the road and trial system, riparian vegetation and fire regime.  Improvements to these indicators will move the Watershed to a Condition Class I.

column22: Sulphur Creek – Lost River watershed is a unique area, both above and below the ground. The Lost River flows through, above and below the limestone karst that underlies much of this watershed. As of July 2008, the Lost River cave system is the second longest cave in Indiana and the 26th longest in the US. One of the significant features of the system, a National Natural Landmark, is Wesley Chapel Gulf, located on National Forest System lands which is 8.3 acres large and forms a box canyon with bedrock walls, where the river briefly appears before once again disappearing below the surface. One Federally endangered species of bat, the Indiana bat (Myotis sodalis), has an identified hibernacula within the watershed.  The area hosts hibernacula for many other bats species. In addition, many Regional Forester Sensitive Species including mammals, birds, fish, reptiles, karst invertebrates, and plants have been identified utilizing this area.  Tributaries and streams in this watershed flow into the East Fork White River which contains Regional Forester Sensitive Species and two endangered mussel species.

column22: Beaver Creek is in the headwaters of the Swan River Sub-Basin and within the Southwest Crown Coordinated Forest Land Restoration Project (CFLRP) Area.  The Swan Valley Grizzly Bear Conservation Agreement requires that large resource management activities be scheduled by Grizzly Bear sub-unit.  The sub-unit containing Beaver Creek will be open for management activities starting in 2012.  Resource issues in this watershed include high road density, forest insects and disease, and noxious weed infestation.

Forests are currently overstocked and have excessive fuel loading. There has been an increase in wildfires with moderate/high burn severity (2011 Beale Fire, 2010 Eagle Rock Fire, 2009 Marteen Fire, and 2000 Pumpkin Fire). Unstable volcanic soils have undergone recurring severe erosion on steeper slopes within burned areas, causing damage to the trails and Forest Service roads and increasing sediment loads in drainages. Soils in the high burn severity areas are expected to take many more years to fully re-stabilize. Forest conditions are contributing to an increased risk of insects and diseases.  The watershed has high road density with insufficient road maintenance to prevent adverse water quality impacts.  Infestations of invasive and noxious weeds including bull thistle (Cirsium vulgare), cheatgrass (Bromus tectorum), and Dalmatian toadflax (Linaria dalmatica) are common in the watershed.  There is potential overgrazing by cattle in wet meadows near Spring Valley Cabin, East Elk Spring, and West Elk Spring.

column22: The main issue with these watersheds is the lodgepole pine mortality due to beetle kill.  Entire stands of lodgepole are infested with mountain pine beetles and the mortality is increasing the potential fire risk.   Infestations are spreading into other stands of lodgepole pine.  The recent absence of fire within these watersheds is also another major concern.  With the amount of dead trees now found in these watersheds, the implication of a larger more severe fire is imminent when the dead trees fall and increase fuel loads.  The lack of fire in aspen has allowed conifer to encroach within the existing stands.  The conifer encroached aspen stands are critical for big game forage and without the fire to regenerate these stands, critical forage is being lost.  Fire would also benefit the Whitebark Pine stands, these stands are currently in decline due to competition from other vegetation, disease, and loss of ability to reproduce due to lack of fire. Portions of the southern end of the watershed area have suitable brood rearing sage grouse habitat.   These areas of sagebrush tend to be older and more decadent and introducing fire back into these areas could improve this sage grouse habitat.  Lastly, there have been some historical impacts due to sheep grazing.  Some areas that were heavily grazed historically are eroded and gullies have formed.  These areas have been identified and could benefit from gully plugging, seeding, and other restoration type projects. Current grazing impacts have been documented where trailing occurs along Indian Creek, Hams Fork River, West Fork Hams Fork, and in certain areas of the uplands.  Grazing cattle and dispersed camping have aided in the spread of invasive plants such as Canada thistle.   Roads located within these watersheds cross many streams and are under-developed for the amount of use they can receive.  Due to the placement and high use, riparian areas are heavily impacted through crossings and sediment inputs.

column22: The watershed has degraded meadows, active headcuts, and approximately 20 miles of stream channel that are in a degraded condition many of which were or are Rosgen F channels. Land management activities and natural disturbances have created conditions that have over time changed riparian communities to xeric vegetation communities such as sagebrush. Rangeland health was declining until 2008 when the Forest started implementing projects that have in some areas started watershed recovery. Rangeland vegetation communities are declining in aerial extent and land is being lost to accelerated erosion. Suitable forage for terrestrial wildlife and grazing animals has a significant departure from desired condition. Water quality impairments include water temperature and sedimentation. Habitat for the TES spotted frog has declined and until 2005 was declining in aerial extent. Soil productivity is impaired and soil erosion rates are above natural background levels. Expansion of Pinyon and Juniper has increased the risk for high intensity wildfire effects. Indian Creek is the headwaters to Reese River Basin which is a municipal watershed for Austin, and occasionally flows to the Humboldt River. The watershed has wet meadow environments that are rare but very important environments in the Great Basin, they account for a large percentage of the region’s biodiversity and have been decreasing in aerial extent in response to channel incision. The watershed serves as important habitat for Columbia spotted frog, Lahontan cutthroat trout, and pygmy rabbit.

column22: The Leech Lake Watershed is located within the Leech Lake River Watershed, a 4th HUC tributary of the Mississippi Headwaters, which joins the Mississippi River at river mile 130.5.  We are working with numerous partners, including the Leech Lake Band of Ojibwe, to protect and improve conditions in watershed by controlling invasive species, acquiring conservation easements or public ownership of lakeshore, and restoring upland forest conditions.  Ongoing work will continue to reduce road densities, treat fuels, reestablish pine forest communities, reduce aquatic fragmentation and diversify riparian vegetation conditions.  This watershed is situated in the heart of Minnesota’s lake country and contains some of the most pristine natural resources in Minnesota. This watershed has a very high degree of biodiversity.  One-half of Minnesota’s naturally producing Muskie lakes and a quarter of the natural Muskie habitat in the United States is located in the watershed.  Forests in the watershed boast the largest number of breeding eagle pairs in the lower 48 states, as well as many other healthy wildlife populations. The State Action Plan for Minnesota Wildlife identified 89  “species of greatest conservation need” including 29 species that are federal or state endangered, threatened, or of special concern within the watershed.  Currently, the watershed meets surface water quality standards for conventional parameter impairments (not including mercury).  However, these resources are experiencing increased pressure from development and subsequent loss of shoreline and aquatic habitat. The surface water resources within this watershed are highly prized for their recreational value and these resources attract several thousand vacationers to the area each year. The protection of these resources is vital in sustaining the natural heritage and character of this watershed.

column22: The MC-BC watershed was selected as a priority watershed in part based on the large area of National Forest land and the valuable resources contained within the watershed boundaries.  Black Creek’s Wild & Scenic River designation, along with the Black Creek Wilderness, are two large natural features in the watershed nationally recognized for their unique values.  Maintenance and enhancement of the watershed is necessary to protect these areas and to enhance all other values contained in the watershed. Noting its significance on a regional scale, the MC-BC watershed is part of the larger Pascagoula River watershed.  Black Creek is a major tributary of the Pascagoula River Basin, the largest unobstructed, naturally flooding river system entering the Gulf of Mexico from the United States.  Maintaining and enhancing the health of the MC-BC watershed has a direct positive effect on the larger                  natural system.

column22: Mill Creek is a unique watershed in Missouri. Within in the watershed Mill Creek is a designated Blue Ribbon trout stream (only one of six wild trout streams in Missouri), high recreational use area (fly fishing, fishing, hiking, horseback riding, and hunting), karst topography (including caves, sinkholes, springs, and perched karst water tables), native plants communities (including cold-water riparian and instream natural communities, dolomite glades, fens, open and closed woodlands, and savannas), includes the natural community Western Star (a proposed State Designated Natural Area), Kaintuck Fen (Federally designated critical habitat for the Hines Emerald Dragonfly), Gray Bat and Indiana Bat Habitat in surrounding area, and documented 152 species of birds (including 124 species of migrant birds – such as 30 species of Warblers and 6 species of Vireo). This watershed is a smaller order watershed, which allows for more success for restoration of surface water and groundwater hydrology, aquatic habitat, riparian vegetation and natural native communities. In addition to 60% Forest Service lands, the Mill Creek watershed includes 1% ownership by the Missouri Department of Conservation (MDC) – known as Bohigian Conservation Area (CA), and the other 39% of the watershed is in private landownership, but most private landowners own large acreage.

column22: The Lower South Fork Two Medicine River is a unique watershed located just south of Glacier National Park and west of the Black Feet Indian Reservation. The watershed is host to a high biological diversity of wildlife species including grizzly bear, timber wolf, Lynxs, wolverine, elk, mule deer, westslope cutthroat trout, harlequin ducks and pika.  In 2007, the Skyland wildfire burned over one-half of the watershed accelerated the spread of invasive weeds, degrading soil conditions and diminishing biodiversity of the watershed. The Rocky Mountain Travel Plan has been completed and the implementation of road decommissioning is a high forest priority. The L&C plans to continue the road work which will have the benefit of lowering the road densities which will eliminate chronic sediment supplies to streams, slowing the spread of noxious weeds and improve the overall watersheds hydrologic function. Grazing within the watershed has resulted in soil damage, streambank/riparian corridor degradation, degraded westslope cutthroat trout habitat, and the spread of invasive weeds. Native species i.e. cutthroat trout are threatened by rainbow trout hybridization and brook trout competition. Potential partnerships will include the Blackfeet Tribe, Glacier Conservation District, Montana Fish Wildlife and Parks, and Trout Unlimited.

column22: The West Branch Presque Isle River watershed contains a portion of the West Branch Presque Isle Wild and Scenic River (WSR), which is a designated scenic segment.  In addition to water quality and free-flowing condition WSR values, the river also has the Outstandingly Remarkable Values (ORVs) of recreation and wildlife.  The West Branch Presque Isle River is a coolwater stream that historically supported large brook trout. Although brook trout and mottled sculpin were present and indicated coldwater habitat, their sample site was dominated by common warmwater minnow species and appeared to be influenced by upstream lake outlets, swamp drainage, and impoundments.  The West Branch Presque Isle River watershed contains eighteen named lakes, of which one (Redboat Lake) is a designated trout lake.  Opportunities to protect and restore the resources of this watershed have been identified through an ongoing planning process.

The Upper Big Creek Watershed includes the upper Big Creek watershed above Rush Creek.  Big Creek drains into the Kings River at Pine Flat Reservoir, which is used to store irrigation water and is a major recreation reservoir in the area.       Watershed Conditions  The watershed is functioning at risk.  Big Creek was first entered in the 1930's with the construction of the Big Creek Road.  This road was later followed by extensive road development on private and public lands in the 1960's and 1980's.  There are approximately 136 miles of road in the watershed.  The Big Creek Watershed has been extensively and intensively managed for timber commodities since the 1930's.  Timber production reached its height in the 1950's when Bretz Mill was in operation in upper Big Creek.  Timber production has been maintained at a steady pace on public and private lands for at least the last 40 years on over 10,000 acres of timber land.  Aquatic Habitat (3.0) Excessive sediment in Big Creek response reaches, known incision and channel erosion in tributaries, riparian recreation sites impacting water quality and channel function.                                                                          Road & Trail Network (2.3) There are approximately 136 miles of road in the watershed, which is considered a high road density.  Several roads and trails are in a degraded condition from a lack of road/trail maintenance and surface water drainage structures.                                                           Soil (1.7) Several soils in the Upper Big Creek watershed are sensitive to soil disturbance including the Holland family of soils.  There are many areas in Holland soils where accelerated erosion has resulted in excessive sedimentation into several channels in the Upper Big Creek watershed.                         Fire Effects & Regime (2.0) There are high fuels on the ground in approximately 50% some areas and potential for high fire severity and high soil burn severity.

column22: The Twomile Creek watershed is a high value cold-water refugia for species that spend a portion of the year or life history in the larger Wild and Scenic Cisco Branch of the Ontonagon River, and move into the cold-water Twomile Creek.  Threats to these resources include climate change, riparian vegetation structure and function, aquatic habitat fragmentation, and water quality.  Opportunities have recently been identified during the planning processes for two large vegetation management projects.  Projects to protect and improve watershed conditions include riparian vegetation treatments and planting, fixing road/stream crossing aquatic organism passage barriers, and improving roads at stream crossings to eliminate sedimentation.  Upland vegetation composition and structure would be moved toward a desired condition through various treatments.

Aquatic habitat is functioning at risk in localized areas due to sedimentation and other impacts from roads, developed and dispersed recreation, livestock grazing, and past mining.  Native fish and amphibian populations are at risk due to the presence of non-native fish species.  There are many partnership opportunities for improving watershd condition.  Pole Creek historically supported bull trout and currently supports ESA listed Chinook salmon and steelhead trout in the lower sections on private land. Pole Creek also supports a region 4 sensitive species westslope cutthroat trout in the headwaters. Area forests provide habitat for the listed Canada lynx, and a number of Region 4 sensitive species, including northern goshawk, flammulated owl, common loon, great gray owl, boreal owl, three-toed woodpecker, and wolverine. Other species of management concern include pileated woodpecker, bighorn sheep, and mountain goat. Whitebark pine recently warranted ESA listing now a Candidate and added to the Region 4 Sensitive plant species occurs in this management area as well as bugleg goldenweed, guardian buckwheat, Stanley’s whitlow-grass, least moonwort, and Stanley thlaspi.  Additionally potential habitat exists for ESA listed Ute ladies’-tresses and Region 4 Sensitive slender moonwort.

column22: The Cedar Creek Watershed contains valuable threatened, endangered, and sensitive species habitat.  The watershed also provides municipal water and is one of the most utilized watersheds for recreation and scenery on the Cleveland.  The watershed also contains one of the Cleveland’s few inventoried roadless areas.  In addition to the resource values stated above and the current watershed issues stated above, the Cedar Creek Watershed is a popular watershed for recreation uses and is a municipal watershed of high interest to the water agencies of the region as well as the Regional Water Quality Control Board.  The watershed is part of the San Diego River, its management and resource value brings together lots of local agencies as well as non-profits.

The main issue with these watersheds is the lodgepole pine mortality due to beetle kill.  Entire stands of lodgepole are infested with mountain pine beetles and the mortality is increasing the potential fire risk.   Infestations are spreading into other stands of lodgepole pine.  The recent absence of fire within these watersheds is also another major concern.  With the amount of dead trees now found in these watersheds, the implication of a larger more severe fire is imminent when the dead trees fall and increase fuel loads.  The lack of fire in aspen has allowed conifer to encroach within the existing stands.  The conifer encroached aspen stands are critical for big game forage and without the fire to regenerate these stands, critical forage is being lost.  Fire would also benefit the Whitebark Pine stands, these stands are currently in decline due to competition from other vegetation, disease, and loss of ability to reproduce due to lack of fire. Portions of the southern end of the watershed area have suitable brood rearing sage grouse habitat.   These areas of sagebrush tend to be older and more decadent and introducing fire back into these areas could improve this sage grouse habitat.  Lastly, there have been some historical impacts due to sheep grazing.  Some areas that were heavily grazed historically are eroded and gullies have formed.  These areas have been identified and could benefit from gully plugging, seeding, and other restoration type projects. Current grazing impacts have been documented where trailing occurs along Indian Creek, Hams Fork River, West Fork Hams Fork, and in certain areas of the uplands.  Grazing cattle and dispersed camping have aided in the spread of invasive plants such as Canada thistle.   Roads located within these watersheds cross many streams and are under-developed for the amount of use they can receive.  Due to the placement and high use, riparian areas are heavily impacted through crossings and sediment inputs.

Eckman Creek is the highest priority subwatershed within the Alsea River focus watershed.  The Forest and its partners have been working in Eckman Creek and the Alsea River for years and are getting close to completing all essential projects.  This subwatershed is a priority with established, high capacity watershed councils and a Stewardship group.

Crazy Creek-Deep Creek directly enters the North Fork Crooked River and has been identified as a critical location for reband trout migration based on fish surveys.  However, there are identified sections that are entrenched, over widened, straightened, contain bank instability, lack large wood and healthy riparian vegetation, have fish barriers and are disconnected from the floodplain.  Recent restoration efforts with partners have improved conditions with the replacement of the number one priority fish barrier culvert of the whole watershed,  as well as some large wood placement,  riparian planting, roadwork, and water developments.  This WCF prioritization would aid in the completion of the subwatershed level restoration.

column22: The Upper San Poil River subwatershed is located within the larger 5th field Upper San Poil River watershed within an existing Watershed Action Plan.  The watershed lies within what was formerly the north half of the Colville Confederated Tribes Reservation and the Colville Tribe has expressed interest in partnering for the overall restoration of the San Poil River of which approximately 80% is on the Reservation.   The river has been a subsistence fishery for the Colville Tribes historically.  In addition, both the Tribes and the Forest Service are interested in recovering the adfluvial and resident populations of interior redband trout and westslope cutthroat trout which are sensitive species.

The key concern is elevated sediment in stream channels, where the mainstem SFSR is 303(d) listed for sediment with a total maximum daily load (TMDL) approved in 1991, the nation’s first non-point source TMDL.  A secondary concern is water temperature and the SFSR and tributary streams are proposed for 303(d) listing (IDEQ 2011 305b report).  To exacerbate the concerns, the 2007 Cascade Complex Wildfire consumed 85% of the watershed, with 76% having moderate to high fire severities.  Eighty-one percent of the RCAs in the watershed experienced uncharacteristic moderate to high fire severities.    The 2000 SFSR Subbasin Review (USDA FS 2000) and 2002 SFSR Subbasin Assessment (IDEQ 2002) identified key watershed issues and developed recommendations to address those issues.  Common in both analyses was that roads continue to be a major issue affecting water quality.  In the 1960s concerns over sedimentation and fish habitat resulted in the Forest Service having a “moratorium” on any further logging and reducing land disturbing activities in the upper SFSR drainage.  Road densities and Riparian Conservation Area (RCA) road densities are high.    “Although large scale ground disturbing activities are non-existent, the roads built during that time continue to be the dominant source of sediment in the subbasin” (IDEQ 2002).   Anthropogenic sediment levels associated with high road densities, trails and dispersed recreational impacts and the anticipated increase of post-wildfire sediment are expected for the next 10 to 20 years which pose a high risk of negatively affecting water quality.  Due to the importance of the watershed for delivering high quality water, three complex watershed restoration planning efforts have occurred since 2008; the 2009 SFSR Recreation Access Management Project, the 2009 Rice Creek Road Restoration Project, and the 2011 SFSR Resource Management Project.

Spring Canyon and Shingle Creek were identified as focus watersheds aimed at addressing insect mortality in the upper Provo drainage along the Mirror Lake Scenic Highway east of Kamas, Utah.  The watershed improvement effort will involve projects designed to improve forest conditions such as fire regime and forest health, and will also likely include some minor improvements to the transportation network.  Though this effort will improve the rating for individual attributes related to forest health and fire regime, it will probably not change the condition class rating.  This is because the primary driver for the existing condition class rating is related to stream channel conditions and Provo Water District’s water augmentation in the main channel.   Spring Canyon and Shingle Creek are classified as functioning at risk (Class 2). Bark beetle epidemic has killed many conifers and are further at risk due to climate change. Dead conifers are at risk of wildfire and several residences and summer home areas are at risk.  d. column22: Jackknife Creek is an important Yellowstone cutthroat fisheries stronghold providing critical habitat.  Stream conditions and functions are classified as fair and could be improved both on FS and private lands.  Efforts have been underway to improve these conditions with essential partnership support.  Three main FS roads split off at the lower end of the subwatershed and parallel Jackknife Creek, Squaw Creek, and Deep Creek each extending about 2-5 miles into the subwatershed and all three streams cross the stream in several locations.  The 2011 high flow event caused an administrative closure on the Squaw Creek to avoid unsafe travel conditions (road washouts).  The last 1.6 miles of the Jackknife road accessing a trailhead has been administratively closed since 2006 due to slumps causing blocked access and unsafe conditions.  These and other roads in the subwatershed could be improved for conditions (drainage), locations (avoiding slumps & riparian areas), and stream crossing. Several of these stream crossing have been identified in the 2005 Caribou-Targhee Fisheries AOP survey as undersized with different degrees of aquatic barriers.  There is a 2011/2012 Legacy project underway to address the last 1.6 miles of the Jackknife Road across unstable slopes and trail access.  The project also includes stream restoration on over 20,000 ft of channel aimed at addressing unstable stream condition associated with undersized stream crossing, historic grazing, beaver removal, poor road locations, etc.  In addition private lands in the lower portion of the drainage have two main restoration projects addressing stream conditions, aquatic barriers and diversion.

The Scriver Creek subwatershed is listed as fully supporting beneficial uses, however; Scriver Creek contributes water to the Middle Fork Payette River which has TMDLs (303d listed) for sediment and temperature. Guidance associated with the TMDL implementation plans for both temperature and sediment identify Scriver Creek as requiring reductions in anthropogenic sediment (76% reduction) and temperature (16% reduction).  Road density is high (4.7 mi/mi2) within the Scriver Creek subwatershed. This high road density is impacting the stream condition by contributing excess sediment to the channel, negatively impacting streambank condition, reducing large woody debris recruitment, expanding the drainage network, increasing stream width to depth ratio, reducing pool quality, and fragmenting aquatic habitat.  A US EPA/IDEQ funded road sediment inventory completed by the Boise National Forest (2011, Scriver Creek GRAIP report) identified approximately 2,500 tons/year of road erosion.  Of this amount and estimated 528 tons/year was delivered to streams in the form of fine sediment.  Fire regimes within the Scriver Creek subwatershed have been altered by fire exclusion. Currently, the subwatershed is rated as having an increased potential for both uncharacteristically large and high intensity/severity wildfire. Scriver Creek provides water to a downstream municipal water supply system for the Rivers Pointe Homeowners Association.  There are 3 known and surveyed fish migration barriers (forest road culverts) that fragment approximately 9.5 miles of available fish habitat.  In addition to these three surveyed fish migration barriers, there are three additional culverts that are thought to be aquatic organism barriers.

Former State of Utah sections 16 and 32 in T15 South, R6 East contain many of these wetlands.  These sections became part of the National Forest System several years ago, but for decades they were used without restriction by visitors.  Several miles of user created roads and motorized trails in these sections are negatively impacting wetlands. The northern two miles of this road is also directly impacting wetlands and the riparian area.  Both drainages provide water for culinary, industrial, and agricultural uses to Emery County. Collectively, these sub-watersheds have impaired ratings for habitat fragmentation, exotic and invasive species, loss of forest cover, mass wasting, and proximity to water. Fish are prevented from moving freely throughout the Left Fork of Huntington Creek aquatic ecosystem due to several reservoirs located in the Left Fork watershed.  There are little to no projects that could be undertaken to mitigate the impaired condition of habitat fragmentation. Exotic and invasive species within the Left Fork of Huntington Creek aquatic ecosystem is typified by the presence of whirling disease and non-native fish species.  Native fish populations are isolated and protected from exotic and invasive species by barriers. There are no additional projects that could reasonably be undertaken to mitigate this impaired condition.

column22: Pine Creek is a first order cold water tributary of the Manistee River, which is a world famous blue ribbon trout stream. The Pine Creek watershed is downstream of all major impoundments on the Manistee River and is one of only two tributaries capable of providing natural reproduction of steelhead trout. The Manistee River itself provides habitat for Lake Sturgeon within the boundaries of this watershed. The Pine Creek watershed provides important habitat for reptile species, including three RFSS turtle species (wood, box, and spotted turtle) and possibly massasauga rattlesnake. There are three bald eagle territories and several red-shouldered hawk territories within the watershed. The watershed includes a portion of the Tippy Bat Swarming Area, important for several species of bats including the endangered Indiana Bat. There is also suitable habitat within the watershed for golden winged warbler, a species under consideration for ESA listing. Several important partners of the Huron-Manistee, including the Michigan Department of Natural Resources, MI Department of Environmental Quality, Conservation Resource Alliance, and Little River Band of Ottawa Indians have great interest in management to protect and improve both aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems within the Pine Creek-Manistee River watershed. Essential projects could be completed in 5 to 8 years depending upon funding availability.

The Caples Creek Watershed contains multiple ecological values of high importance.  The watershed contains the Mokelumne Wilderness, Round Top Botany-Geology Special Interest Area, Caples Creek Recommended Wilderness, and Caples Creek (Wild and Scenic River Eligible).  Sierra Nevada yellow-legged frogs, a Forest Service sensitive species and a candidate for listing, have been documented in the watershed.  Caples Creek is a Class I productive stream with brown trout and rainbow trout; and is inventoried as potential habitat for sensitive plant species because of its upper elevation range.  Potential water quality impacts, invasive species presence, degraded vegetation conditions, and degraded habitat conditions have been documented in some areas.  Improvements are needed to achieve desired conditions for important ecological values and to support other beneficial uses within the watershed.

column22: In 2005, a working group comprised of key stakeholders representing 14 entities convened in a series of meetings to develop an aquatic habitat restoration strategy for the Hood River Basin.  The Hood River Aquatic Restoration Strategy is a basin wide strategy identifying priority watersheds, limiting factors, and priority hilltop-to-valley-bottom restoration actions.  The goal of the strategy was to address aquatic habitat restoration needs for fish species, stream flow, and water quality improvements.  This strategy is the foundation for the Upper West Fork Hood River Watershed Restoration Action Plan.  The Upper west Fork Hood River (UWFHR) watershed is a priority watershed because: 1) The UWFHR supports summer steelhead and spring Chinook salmon.  Spring Chinook salmon are listed as threatened under the ESA and are culturally important to the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs Reservation (CTWS).  The population of summer steelhead is one of a few remnant wild populations remaining in the Lower Columbia River basin.  2) The watershed is the primary focus of multi-agency restoration efforts with strong partnerships and strong financial commitments.  3) The UWFHR is a priority for the CTWS because it is the stronghold for spring Chinook salmon production.  Due to the agreement between Columbia River tribes and BPA, the CTWS has a long term source of funding for habitat restoration, fish population supplementation, and population monitoring.  4) Western Rivers Conservancy is working in partnership with the MHNF to acquire an 1872 acre private parcel in the UWFHR.  Upon acquisition, Western Rivers Conservancy will make the parcel available to the Forest Service, which includes three miles of spawning and rearing habitat for listed fish.  5) Several restoration projects identified in the 2006 Hood River Basin Aquatic Restoration Strategy have already been completed and there is strong momentum.             .

column22: The Camp Creek Watershed (5th field) is home to Chinook salmon, steelhead, bull trout, redband trout and Pacific lamprey.  This watershed is situated in the John Day Basin, which is widely regarded as "the Columbia Basin's most biologically diverse river system and a globally important stronghold of wild salmon" (www.wildsalmoncenter.org).  The John Day River is the longest free-flowing river in the Columbia Basin and the second longest free flowing river in the 48 conterminous United States (CBMRC&D 2005), providing relatively unencumbered access to basin watersheds, such as Camp Creek.  Further, the basin is relatively free of hatchery influences (Carmichael 2007), thereby supporting the last remaining intact wild spring Chinook and steelhead populations in the Columbia basin (CBMRC&D 2005). Unfortunately, John Day River Basin spring Chinook salmon and steelhead numbers are considerably lower than historic levels.  To address the sharp decline in fish numbers, the state of Oregon, National Marine Fisheries Service, and the Northwest Power and Conservation Council have developed largescale recovery plans.  The Conservation and Recovery Plan for Oregon Steelhead Populations in the Middle Columbia River Steelhead Distinct Population Segment (Carmichael 2009) rated the Camp Creek watershed as a high priority for habitat protection and restoration in the Middle Fork John Day River subbasin.  The John Day Subbasin Revised Draft Plan (CBMRC&D) listed Camp Creek as the highest priority watershed.

column22: The Camp Creek Watershed (5th field) is home to spring Chinook salmon, steelhead, bull trout, redband trout, and Pacific lamprey.  This watershed is situated in the John Day River Basin, which is widely regarded as "the columbia Basin's most biologically diverse river system and a globally important stronghold of wild salmon" (www.wildsalmoncenter.org).  The John Day River is the longest free-flowing river in the Columbia Basin and the second longest free flowing river in the 48 conterminous United States (CBMRC&D 2005), providing relatively unencumbered access to basin watersheds, such as Camp Creek.  Further, the basin is relatively free of hatchery influences (Carmichael 2007), thereby suppporting the last remaining intact wild spring Chinook salmon and steelhead populations in the Columbia basin (CBMRC&D 2005).  Unfortunately, John Day River Basin spring Chinook and steelhead numbers are considerably lower than historic levels.  To address this sharp decline in fish numbers, the state of Oregon, National marine Fisheries Service, and the Northwest Power and Conservation Counciil have developed large-scale recovery plans.  The Conservation and Recovery Plan for Orgon Steelhead Populations in the Middle Columbia River Steelhead Distinct Population Segement (Carmichael 2009) rated the Camp Creek watershed as a high priority for habitat protection and restoration in the Middle Fork John Day River subbasin.  the John Day Subbasin Revised Draft Plan (CBMRC&D 2005) listed Camp Creek as the highest priority watershed.

column22: Erosion related issues associated with system trails in this High Uintas Wilderness watershed.  Primary concern is with a seven mile long primitive road segment in the watershed created prior to wilderness designation.  This road was used to transport heavy equipment during construction of dams in the 1950’s to facilitate irrigation in the lower valleys.  Numerous segments of this road are on steep slopes and/or lack drainage features to prevent capture of streams and overland storm flow.  Restoration efforts to narrow the tread and correct erosion problems with this system trail would reduce sediment transport to area streams, reduce soil loss, and improve the wilderness character of the watershed.  Approximately 2.5 miles of system trail elsewhere in the watershed have also been identified as needing improvement to correct problems related to water drainage or accelerated soil erosion.   Designated wilderness (High Uintas Wilderness Area).

Segments of Giles Creek and riparian areas are not in Proper Functioning Condition.  There is not enough late seral native vegetation to support habitat requirements for Management Indicator Species and Sensitive Species.  Expansion and invasion of undesired non-native vegetation, particularly crested wheatgrass and Kentucky bluegrass, is occurring.  In places, bare ground and absence of litter from overgrazing is affecting plant vigor, species composition, and forage production.  Goals are to move all riparian areas into Proper Functioning Condition; meet the Dakota Prairie Grasslands LRMP objectives for vegetative structure to improve habitat for Management Indicator Species; expand the presence of desired native grass species; reduce noxious weeds; and maintain positive working relationship with the Grand River Cooperative Grazing Association.

column22: The watershed is considered functioning at risk.  The three main conditions contributing to the functioning at risk classification include; loss of ecosystem health caused by a wide spread beetle epidemic, introduced non-native fish species threatening native bull trout populations, and heavy recreation pressure including need for trail maintenance and OHV use management.  The Sawmill area is currently experiencing a Douglas-fir bark beetle and spruce budworm epidemic. The watershed has experienced a large buildup of forest fuels and change in vegetation composition and structure. Exceptionally dense stands are undergoing intense completion for limited amounts of water, nutrients, and sunlight. These conditions, in combination with recent long-term drought, have led to recent and ongoing insect epidemics and high intensity wildfires around the project area. The development of mid to late-seral stand structures and species composition favors conifer species over aspen. As a result, aspen stands are declining reducing the diversity and overall resiliency of the ecosystem.  Introduced brook trout appear to be a major threat to bull trout (Endangered Species Act Threatened species) populations in the Little Lost River basin.  The Sawmill Canyon sub-watershed upstream from, and including, Iron Creek contains approximately 22 miles of occupied bull trout habitat and approximately 95% of the bull trout found in the Little Lost River basin. Additional assessments have concluded that brook trout will completely replace bull trout within the next 50 years if management action is not taken.

The primary concerns in this watershed center on fire susceptibility and sediment contributions from roads to streams.  This watershed has a moderate to high fire susceptibility rating.  The upper reaches of the watershed border on wildland-urban interfaces, it contains significant cultural resource (both historic and pre-historic), and contains portions of four giant sequoia groves. This watershed contains a Critical Aquatic Refuge, providing habitat for native fish, amphibian, and aquatic invertebrate populations.  Fire is a threat to all of these resources plus the watershed itself.  Watershed related road inventory work has been completed and shows a significant amount of sediment delivery from the road system that lies within this watershed.  General road maintenance activities, road drainage reconstruction for aquatic fish passage (culvert replacement, over-side drainage repair, etc.), and road decommissioning work has been identified and is needed within this watershed.  This watershed contains invasive starthistle and invasive Sacramento Perch.

column22: The West Fork of Fishtrap Creek supports the bulk of fluvial bull trout spawning in the Fishtrap Creek watershed.  This is a bull trout priority watershed and one of the two most important bull trout areas in the larger Thompson River system.   Improvements will directly benefit bull trout populations and will improve water quality for the West Fork Fishtrap Creek as well as downstream reaches of Fishtrap Creek (habitat, sediment and temperature).

The watershed contains a variety of ecological stream types including high and lower quality native brook trout habitat but has been impacted by historic logging, a number of road problems and high beaver activity.  Many of the roads within the area have been in place since the early logging era where they have contributed to changes in drainage patterns, increased sediment loads, fish passage problems, and loss of riparian habitat.  This watershed provides one the greatest diversity of watershed improvement projects on Forest.  In addition the watershed is adjacent to another priority watershed on Forest, Twentymile Creek.  These two watersheds offer the best opportunity to collaborate efforts with the Bad River Watershed Association who is in the process of finalizing their HUC 5 Marengo River watershed action plan.  The watershed is located within the Great Lakes basin.

column22: The primary concerns in this watershed center on sediment and non-point-source pollution contributions from roads and dispersed recreation sites to streams. column22: Forests are currently overstocked and have excessive fuel loading. The majority of the watershed is in Fire Regime Condition Class 3 and is at risk of uncharacteristically large, high-severity, stand replacing wildfire that could adversely affect the City of Williams.  Forest conditions are also contributing to an increased risk of insects and diseases, particularly mistletoe infection.  Juniper encroachment into grassland ecosystems have resulted in decreased vegetative ground cover in some areas, increasing the risk of soil erosion. The watershed has high road density (3.26 mi./sq. mi.) with insufficient road maintenance to prevent adverse surface water quality impacts.
